facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 3 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 3 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 20, 1961 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 124 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 20, 1961 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 124 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by AYYANGAR J. on July 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: July 31, 1963. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the appellant's appeal against conviction and sentence by Sessions Judge, Champaran.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Patna dismissing an appeal by the appellant against his conviction and the sentence passed on him by the Sessions Judge, Champaran.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by Sessions Judge, Champaran under Section 304A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing an appeal by the appellant against his conviction and the sentence passed on him by the Sessions Judge, Champaran. The appellant was charged with an offence under S. 304A

facts.text: Incident occurred on July 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: occurrence-July 16, 1959, with the result that her latrine had become exposed to public view.

facts.text: Wall of the deceased's latrine fell down about a week prior to July 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: latrine had fallen down about a week prior to the day of the occurrence-July 16, 1959, with the result that her latrine had become exposed to public view.

facts.text: Deceased Mst. Madilen was an inmate of a house near that of the accused.

anchor.surface_text: causing the death of one Mst. Madilen by contact with an electrically charged naked copper wire which he had fixed up at the back of his house with a view to prevent the entry of intruders into his latrine. The deceased Madilen was an inmate

facts.text: Deceased and others started using the accused's latrine after her own latrine wall fell.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the deceased among others, started using the latrine of the accused. The accused resented this and made it clear to them that they did not have his permission to use it and protested against their coming there.

facts.text: Accused resented use of his latrine and protested orally without permission.

anchor.surface_text: The accused resented this and made it clear to them that they did not have his permission to use it and protested against their coming there. The oral warnings, however, proved ineffective

facts.text: Oral warnings by accused proved ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: The oral warnings, however, proved ineffective and it was for this reason that on the facts, as found by the courts below,

facts.text: Accused fixed a naked uninsulated copper wire across the passage leading to his latrine carrying current from his house wiring to make entry dangerous.

anchor.surface_text: the accused fixed up a copper wire across the passage leading up to his latrine,  2  that this wire was naked and uninsulated and carried current from the electrical wiring of his house to which it was connected,

facts.text: There was no warning that the wire was live.

anchor.surface_text: 3  there was no warning that the wire was live,  4  the deceased managed to pass into the latrine without contacting the wire

facts.text: Deceased entered latrine without contacting wire but touched it with hand while coming out, got electric shock and died soon after.

anchor.surface_text: the deceased managed to pass into the latrine without contacting the wire but that as she came out her hand happened to touch it and she got a shock as a result of which she died soon after.

facts.text: Some prosecution facts were disputed by accused but concluded by findings of courts below and not challenged in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Though some of the facts alleged by the prosecution were disputed by the accused, they are concluded by the findings of the courts below and are no longer open to challenge and, indeed, learned Counsel for the appellant did not attempt to controvert them.

facts.text: Courts below held accused guilty under Section 304A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the Courts below held that the accused was guilty of an offence under s. 304A of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Accused also charged under Section 304 IPC but acquitted as no intention to cause death.

anchor.surface_text: It might be mentioned that the accused was also charged before the learned Sessions Judge with an offence under section 304 of the Indian Penal Code but on the finding that the accused had no intention to cause the death of the deceased he was acquitted of that charge.

facts.text: At time of accident, it was past day break with enough light.

anchor.surface_text: The accused made a suggestion that the deceased had been sufficiently warned and the facts relied on in this connection were two  1  that at the time of the accident it was past day break and there was therefore enough light,

facts.text: An electric light was burning some distance away at time of accident.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that an electric light was burning some distance away. But it is manifest that neither of these could constitute warning

facts.text: Voltage of current in wire was high enough to be lethal.

anchor.surface_text: The voltage of the current passing through the naked wire being high enough to be lethal, there could be no dispute that charging it with current of that voltage was a rash act

facts.text: Patna High Court repelled defence of right of private defence of property.

anchor.surface_text: The principal point of law which appears to have been argued before the learned judges of the High Court was that the accused had a right of private defence of property and that the death was caused in the course of the exercise of that right. The learned judges repelled this defence

concepts.unlisted_description: Whoever causes death by rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide

anchor.surface_text: s. 304A of the Indian Penal Code which en- acts 304A. Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

anchor.surface_text: A trespasser is not an outlaw, a Caput lupinem. The mere fact that the person entering a land is a trespasser does not entitle the owner or occupier to inflict on him personal injury by direct violence and the same principle would govern the infliction of injury by indirectly doing something on the land the effect of which he must know was likely to cause serious injury to the trespasser. Thus in England it has been held that one who sets springguns to shoot at trespassers is guilty of a tort and that the person injured is entitled to recover.

concepts.interpretation: Occupier cannot set traps like spring guns or live wires intended to cause bodily harm to known trespassers; even trespassers have protection against willful harm.

concepts.unlisted_label: No traps for trespassers (common law principle)
concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibition on occupiers setting man-traps or equivalent for trespassers; cited from English law and UK Law Reform Committee

arguments.claim: Charging the naked uninsulated wire with lethal voltage current was a rash act in reckless disregard of consequences

anchor.surface_text: The voltage of the current passing through the naked wire being high enough to be lethal, there could be no dispute that charging it with current of that voltage was a rash act done in reckless disregard of the serious consequences to people coming in contact with it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Right under s.97 subject to s.99; type of injury from trap not within scope of s.99 or s.103

arguments.claim: Right of private defence of property under s.97 IPC is subject to s.99 and trap causing such injury is not permitted

anchor.surface_text: The right of private defence of property which is set out in s. 97 of the Indian Penal Code is, as that section itself provides, subject to the provisions of s. 99 of the Code. It is obvious that the type of injury caused by the trap laid by the accused cannot be brought within the scope of s. 99, number of course of s. 103 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Deceased was a trespasser so occupier owed no duty, no cause of action in tort for injury, hence act not a crime

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel, however, tried to adopt a different approach. The contention was that the deceased was a trespasser and that there was no duty owed by an occupier like the accused towards the trespasser and therefore the latter would have had no cause of action for damages for the injury inflicted and that if the act of the accused was not a tort, it could not also be a crime.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n for damages for the injury inflicted and that if the act of the accused was number a tort, it companyld number also be a crime. There is numbersubst

arguments.court_reasoning: IPC is complete code defining crimes and defences, no invocation of common law; even otherwise, act is tortious as occupier cannot set traps for trespassers

arguments.claim: IPC comprehensively defines crimes and available defences so common law principles outside Code cannot be invoked to negate criminality

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in this line of argument. In the first place, where we have a Code like the Indian Penal Code which defines with particularity the ingredients of a crime and the defences open to an accused charged with any of the offences there set out we consider that it would not be proper or justifiable to permit the invocation of some Common Law principle outside that Code for the purpose of treating what on the words of the statute is a crime into a permissible or other than unlawful act.

arguments.claim: Even towards trespassers, occupier cannot inflict personal injury by traps like spring guns or naked live wires as trespasser not outlaw

anchor.surface_text: But that apart, learned Counsel is also not right in his submission that the act of the accused as a result of which the deceased suffered injuries resulting in her death was not an actionable wrong. A trespasser is not an outlaw, a Caput lupinem. The mere fact that the person entering a land is a trespasser does not entitle the owner or occupier to inflict on him personal injury by direct violence and the same principle would govern the infliction of injury by indirectly doing something on the land the effect of which he must know was likely to cause serious injury to the trespasser.

holdings.text: Charging the naked uninsulated wire with lethal voltage current without warning constitutes a rash act done in reckless disregard of serious consequences, amounting to an offence under Section 304A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The voltage of the current passing through the naked wire being high enough to be lethal, there could be no dispute that charging it with current of that voltage was a rash act done in reckless disregard of the serious consequences to people coming in contact with it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of naked live wire with lethal voltage, no warning, accepted from lower courts; daylight and distant light insufficient to warn of charge; directly applies s.304A to facts.

holdings.text: It is manifest that neither daylight past daybreak nor distant electric light constitutes warning that the wire was charged with electric current.

anchor.surface_text: But it is manifest that neither of these could constitute warning as the conditions of the wire being charged with electric current could not obviously be de- tected merely by the place being properly lit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Visibility of light does not reveal invisible electric charge; rejects petitioner's evidence sufficiency claim.

holdings.text: The right of private defence of property under s.97 IPC is subject to s.99 and s.103; the type of lethal injury caused by the trap (naked live wire) laid by the accused cannot be brought within the scope of s.99 or s.103.

anchor.surface_text: The right of private defence of property which is set out in s. 97 of the Indian Penal Code is, as that section itself provides, subject to the provisions of s. 99 of the Code. It is obvious that the type of injury caused by the trap laid by the accused cannot be brought within the scope of s. 99, not of course of s. 103 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory limits on private defence exclude traps causing excessive injury; agrees with High Court repelling defence.

holdings.text: Where the Indian Penal Code defines crimes and defences with particularity, it is not proper to invoke Common Law principles outside the Code to treat a statutory crime as permissible.

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in this line of argument. In the first place, where we have a Code like the Indian Penal Code which defines with particularity the ingredients of a crime and the defences open to an accused charged with any of the offences there set out we consider that it would not be proper or justifiable to permit the invocation of some Common Law principle outside that Code for the purpose of treating what on the words of the statute is a crime into a permissible or other than unlawful act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: IPC is comprehensive code; external principles cannot negate defined offences.

holdings.text: Even assuming arguendo, the act of setting a naked live wire trap for known trespassers is an actionable tort as occupiers cannot inflict willful personal injury on trespassers who are not outlaws; equivalent to spring guns prohibited in English law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative ground: trespassers entitled to protection against willful traps causing bodily harm; analogies to English spring gun cases and UK Law Reform Committee; policy of civilized behaviour.

justification_sets.label: Right of private defence of property support

edges.explanation: h4 holds that where IPC defines crimes and defences with particularity, it is not proper to invoke common law principles outside the Code to treat statutory crime as permissible, directly addressing the issue i3 of invoking common law for no duty to trespasser.

anchor.surface_text: There is no substance in this line of argument. In the first place, where we have a Code like the Indian Penal Code which defines with particularity the ingredients of a crime and the defences open to an accused charged with any of the offences there set out we consider that it would not be proper or justifiable to permit the invocation of some Common Law principle outside that Code for the purpose of treating what on the words of the statute is a crime into a permissible or other than unlawful act.

The learned judges repelled this defence and in our opinion, quite companyrectly. The right of private defence of property which is set out in s. 97 of the Indian Penal Code is, as that section itself provides, subject to the provisions of s. 99 of the Code.

edges.explanation: h5 holds that setting naked live wire trap for known trespassers is actionable tort as occupiers cannot inflict willful personal injury on trespassers, supporting the common law principle c12 of no traps for trespassers.
h5 even assuming arguendo the common law position invoked in i3, holds the act of setting live wire trap is actionable tort, addressing the issue.
